What specifically makes a wrong immoral?  The moral code you use to compare it to... assuming you *have* a moral code to compare it to. If you have no morals, then it is difficult to see whether or not something that is wrong, is also immoral.  If you do have morals, then you would already know if something is immoral, regardless of whether or not it was considered "wrong". Is it wrong or immoral to execute criminals?  Is wrong or immoral to kill enemy combatants in war?  Is wrong or immoral to kill your neighbor because he plays music too loud? Three cases where a conscious decision ends the life of another human being.  Your morals decide which is immoral.  There are those who believe that ending ANY human life for ANY reason is immoral.  There are those who believe that killing in war is a necessity, but otherwise even capital punishment is wrong.  There are those who would never take a life themselves, but believe that capital punishment is necessary in a day and age when criminals are actually being made better criminals in the correctional system we currently have.  Then there are those who live by the moral code of "Fuck with me and die." So... what makes a wrong, immoral?  The same thing that makes anything else immoral.  The moral code it is framed within.
